prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Sensitivity has bene chosen to be 80 mJy in a 0.5 km/s bin. Given that the brightness of [CI] 2--1 at the actual position of HH46 using APEX is 140 Jy, we will be able to detect any structure, even if the [CI] 1--0 is very smoothly distributed across the APEX region. A ratio of 2--1/1--0 of 0.7 is used as reference. Note that at the bow shock, [CI] 2--1 is even brighter than 140 Jy.
Unresolved peaks of 1 Jy along the wall are common IF the CO is dissociated all along the surface PDRs. This will be detected with a SNR of ~16 per channel. Non-detections can be improved by binning to 2 km/s. However, non-detections are key to constrain the UV-field. As such this high sensitivity is vital.

The main spectral window is tuned to [CI] 1-0 with a resolution of 0.1 km/s. This was done as [CI] is expected to be very narrow (following APEX detections), but also because it is unknown whether the APEX detections are a superposition of even narrower lines or broadened from turbulent motions in a PDR. This resolution will resolve that question.
The other three spectral windows are tuned to continuum and the lines of CS and SiO. These lines have an almost completely unknown emission profile. As such it is likely an interesting project to compare low-J CS/SiO to the high-J CS/SiO obtained here.

This science goal covers the Band 8 [CI] line in a triangular shape Nyquist sampled map of the inner 18". The resolution of 0.25 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the thickness of the PDR at the cavity wall , estimated from Arce et al., 2013.
Due to the complete lack of information on the distribution, ACA is a required element of this proposal. [CI] is expected not to be extended beyond 6 arcseconds here, so no TP is needed.

Sensitivity has been chosen to be 150 mJy in a 0.5 km/s bin. Following the simulations of Fig. 3 we will be able to detect any structure, even if the CO 6--5 is very smoothly distributed across the region. The APEX emission of the center 8$''$ region showed a line of nearly 500 Jy. The high sensitivity is vital to resolve the line profile in all but the weakest emitting regions. Non-detections will then indicate a complete absence of warm CO gas. The CO 1--0 will be used as reference if cold CO gas is present at these locations.

The main window is tuned to CO 6--5, the most important line of this proposal. It has a resolution of 0.1 km/s which will greatly overresolve shocked emission. However, it is a necessary resolution to be able to identify the narrow resolution that was seen by APEX. Even though lines are 2 km/s wide there, those might be a superposition of narrow lines at different velocities. The other three windows are for the continuum, which greatly improve calibration at Band 9. They are also covering likely emission lines (CS and C17O), although little to no information exist how bright these are expected to be. That depends highly on the heating effects. If detected they may greatly aid the analysis. Their resolution has been set in such a way data rate is not exceeded.

This science goal covers the Band 9 CO 6--5 line in a small triangle mosaic 18" on the side near the protostellar position. The resolution of 0.25 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the thickness of the PDR at the cavity wall , estimated from Arce et al., 2013. Six arcseconds is sufficient to pick up any large-scale emission in warm gas, which is thought to be highly structured.
Due to the complete lack of information on the distribution, ACA i a required element of this proposal. Although not offered (TP at high frequencies), the Total power emission of many positions in CO 6--5 is obtained through the old APEX data.

Sensitivity has bene chosen to be 80 mJy in a 0.5 km/s bin. Given that the brightness of [CI] 2--1 at the actual position of HH46 using APEX is 140 Jy, we will be able to detect any structure, even if the [CI] 1--0 is very smoothly distributed across the APEX region. A ratio of 2--1/1--0 of 0.7 is used as reference. Note that at the bow shock, [CI] 2--1 is even brighter than 140 Jy.
Unresolved peaks of 1 Jy along the wall are common IF the CO is dissociated all along the surface PDRs. This will be detected with a SNR of ~16 per channel. Non-detections can be improved by binning to 2 km/s. However, non-detections are key to constrain the UV-field. As such this high sensitivity is vital.

The main spectral window is tuned to [CI] 1-0 with a resolution of 0.1 km/s. This was done as [CI] is expected to be very narrow (following APEX detections), but also because it is unknown whether the APEX detections are a superposition of even narrower lines or broadened from turbulent motions in a PDR. This resolution will resolve that question.
The other three spectral windows are tuned to continuum and the lines of CS and SiO. These lines have an almost completely unknown emission profile. As such it is likely an interesting project to compare low-J CS/SiO to the high-J CS/SiO obtained here.

This science goal covers the Band 8 [CI] line for the 9 separate positions to cover the outflow cavity wall. The resolution of 0.25 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the thickness of the PDR at the cavity wall , estimated from Arce et al., 2013.
Due to the complete lack of information on the distribution, ACA is a required element of this proposal. [CI] is expected not to be extended beyond 6 arcseconds here, so no TP is needed.

This science goal covers the Band 8 [CI] line in 17 pointings.
Pointings consist of 9 specifically selected positions along the flow and a triangular shape Nyquist sampled map of the inner 18" or so.
Sensitivity has bene chosen to be 60 mJy in a 0.5 km/s bin. Given that the brightness of [CI] 2--1 at the actual position of HH46 using APEX is 140 Jy, we will be able to detect any structure, even if the [CI] 1--0 is very smoothly distributed across the APEX region. RADEX modelling showed [CI] brightness Note that at the bow shock, [CI] 2--1 is even brighter than 140 Jy. Unresolved peaks of 1 Jy along the wall are common IF the CO is dissociated all along the surface PDRs. This will be detected with a SNR of ~16 per channel. Non-detections can be improved by binning to 2 km/s. However, non-detections are key to constrain the UV-field. As such this high sensitivity is vital.
Due to the complete lack of information on the distribution, ACA and Total power are a required element of this proposal.
The other three spectral windows are tuned to continuum and the lines of CS and SiO. These lines have an almost completely unknown emission profile. As such it is likely an interesting project to compare low-J CS/SiO to the high-J CS/SiO obtained here.

The main window is tuned to CO 6--5, the most important line of this proposal. It has a resolution of 0.1 km/s which will greatly overresolve shocked emission. However, it is a necessary resolution to be able to identify the narrow resolution that was seen by APEX. Even though lines are 2 km/s wide there, those might be a superposition of narrow lines at different velocities. The other three windows are for the continuum, which greatly improve calibration at Band 9. They are also covering likely emission lines (CS and C17O), although little to no information exist how bright these are expected to be. That depends highly on the heating effects. If detected they may greatly aid the analysis. Their resolution has been set in such a way data rate is not exceeded.

This science goal covers the Band 9 CO 6--5 line in individual pointings along the flow. The resolution of 0.25 arcsec is sufficient to resolve the thickness of the PDR at the cavity wall , estimated from Arce et al., 2013. Six arcseconds is sufficient to pick up any large-scale emission in warm gas, which is thought to be highly structured.
Due to the complete lack of information on the distribution, ACA i a required element of this proposal. Although not offered (TP at high frequencies), the Total power emission of many positions in CO 6--5 is obtained through the old APEX data.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: How energy is transported across outflow cavity walls onto the cold surrounding cloud material is virtually unknown. Although existing observations readily show the cavities and the cavity walls, they lack the spatial resolution to study the precise location and structure of the surface PDR through observations of the warm molecular and/or atomic gas. Clear variations in the gas distributions along the flows have been revealed. A large number of possible scenarios have been proposed for the heating effects. Most likely, multiple scenarios actually coexist within one flow, depending on local conditions and internal UV radiation. The best-studied outflow to date is HH-46/47. We propose to use ALMA to observe 17-21 positions along its red lobe. By targetting CO 65 and [CI] 1-0 transitions at 0.3 spatial resolution, the emission profiles of both the molecular and atomic gas located within or behind the surface PDR and within the cavity will be spatially and spectrally resolved. This allows us to directly image the structure of the cavity wall, unambigiously determine the gas distribution of the PDR layer(s) and thus derive how energy is transported across the cavity wall.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal is a resubmission of the accepted Cycle 2 proposal 2013.1.001202.S, which has not yet been observed due to weather limitations. Science Goals obtained within the existing Cycle 2 program do not have to be repeated for this proposal. However, for the scientific goals to be reached, all Science Goals need to be executed.
